properties.media:imagetext:
CHINA AIRWAYS FEDERAL INC. U. S. A.
3 CANTON ROAD
SHANGHAI
NORTH AMERICAN AVIATION, INC.
INTERCONTINENT AVIATION, INC.
CURTISS-WRIGHT CORPORATION
CURTISS AEROPLANE AND MOTOR COMPANY
WRIGHT AERONAUTICAL CORPORATION
CURTISS. WRIGHT AIRPLANE COMPANY
DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT COMPANY
SPERRY GYROSCOPE COMPANY
HANKOW, Saturday, June 3, 1933.
Dear
Family:
We arrived here yesterday afternoon at
5 P.M.
after a
beautiful and most
interesting trip down
from Chungking through the gorges.
We flew low in a regular
Loening with landing wheels removed - in other words a flying
boat.
The pilot who has been flying this 500-mile-route for
nearly two years
is a great character.
He is from Nashville
and knows the Holdneress and others
from there.
He is very
good looking - a big fellow about 5:11 and weighs 180 or
thereabouts
- his drawl is not very pronounced but you would
know he hails from the South.
His name is Charles
S.
Vaughn
but he is known
on every steamboat, gunboat,
ci ty
and
town -
by all nationalities including Chinese as
"Chilly".
All up
and down
the upper Yangtze for the 500 miles the expression
"Here comes
Chilly" is a part of the every day language and
among the Chinese
"Here comes Chilly" means aviation or air
mail.
He has a flat in Hankow where lots of passenger and
all
the pilots make their headquarters.
He charges the
pilots
on
the lower river run $6.00 Mex. per day and they
sign "chits" for drinks or extras. (Any memo, short note
or
club slip over here is a "chit")
He has a good Chinese boy
as cook and another as
servant - press suits, shine shoes, etc.
When Chilly goes along
the river all the boats whistle a
salute
and Chilly flashes the most engaging smile you've ever
seen and waves to crew and passengers as he roars by.
He has
a stop at Ichang where
the gorges begin and there is
stationed
the American "flag-pan"
as the naval officers call the flag
the Yangtsze River flat bottomed gun boats.
sanded on at on near t bottle an boo a am ral
called out "come on over Chilly" so we got in a sampan and
jointed the officers on the Luzon,
which is the "flag-pans"
official name,
and had a cup of
coffee and a sandwich while
Chilly's Chinese co-pilot Hugh Chen was supervising the
refueling of the ship.
I noticed as we approached the flag
ship that all
the sailors and even the cook said "Hello Chilly".
If he gets stuck at Ichang, Chilly boards the Luzon with any
foreign passengers he may have and spends the night on board
flying on
the
next morning to
Chungking.
In two years he has
never had an accident of any kind and he is so well known
that his plane is filled to capacity on almost every trip.
He
writes notes to the foreign passengers and Chen writes notes
to the Chinese
passengers pointing out interesting places, etc.
At Chungking
Chilly had a flat but every time he arrived there
different people insisted on entertaining him and so he gave
up his flat and for two years has stayed with friends up there.

CHINA AIRWAYS FEDERAL INC. U. S. A.
3 CANTON ROAD
SHANGHAI
NORTH AMERICAN AVIATION, INC.
INTERCONTINENT AVIATION, INC.
CURTISS-WRIGHT CORPORATION
CURTISS AEROPLANE AND MOTOR COMPANY
WRIGHT AERONAUTICAL CORPORATION
CURTISS. WRIGHT AIRPLANE COMPANY
DOUGLAS AIRCRAFT COMPANY
SPERRY GYROSCOPE COMPANY
HANKOW, Saturday, June 3, 1933.
Dear
Family:
We arrived here yesterday afternoon at
5 P.M.
after a
beautiful and most
interesting trip down
from Chungking through the gorges.
We flew low in a regular
Loening with landing wheels removed - in other words a flying
boat.
The pilot who has been flying this 500-mile-route for
nearly two years
is a great character.
He is from Nashville
and knows the Holdneress and others
from there.
He is very
good looking - a big fellow about 5:11 and weighs 180 or
thereabouts
- his drawl is not very pronounced but you would
know he hails from the South.
His name is Charles
S.
Vaughn
but he is known
on every steamboat, gunboat,
ci ty
and
town -
by all nationalities including Chinese as
"Chilly".
All up
and down
the upper Yangtze for the 500 miles the expression
"Here comes
Chilly" is a part of the every day language and
among the Chinese
"Here comes Chilly" means aviation or air
mail.
He has a flat in Hankow where lots of passenger and
all
the pilots make their headquarters.
He charges the
pilots
on
the lower river run $6.00 Mex. per day and they
sign "chits" for drinks or extras. (Any memo, short note
or
club slip over here is a "chit")
He has a good Chinese boy
as cook and another as
servant - press suits, shine shoes, etc.
When Chilly goes along
the river all the boats whistle a
salute
and Chilly flashes the most engaging smile you've ever
seen and waves to crew and passengers as he roars by.
He has
a stop at Ichang where
the gorges begin and there is
stationed
the American "flag-pan"
as the naval officers call the flag
the Yangtsze River flat bottomed gun boats.
sanded on at on near t bottle an boo a am ral
called out "come on over Chilly" so we got in a sampan and
jointed the officers on the Luzon,
which is the "flag-pans"
official name,
and had a cup of
coffee and a sandwich while
Chilly's Chinese co-pilot Hugh Chen was supervising the
refueling of the ship.
I noticed as we approached the flag
ship that all
the sailors and even the cook said "Hello Chilly".
If he gets stuck at Ichang, Chilly boards the Luzon with any
foreign passengers he may have and spends the night on board
flying on
the
next morning to
Chungking.
In two years he has
never had an accident of any kind and he is so well known
that his plane is filled to capacity on almost every trip.
He
writes notes to the foreign passengers and Chen writes notes
to the Chinese
passengers pointing out interesting places, etc.
At Chungking
Chilly had a flat but every time he arrived there
different people insisted on entertaining him and so he gave
up his flat and for two years has stayed with friends up there.

- 2-
Well so much for Chilly - you may meet him
because he is going home on leave in August and maybe to get
married although he
claims his girl is still saying "no"
instead of "yas".
He has been over here 3 years and all
pilots get 3
months home with expenses and full pay every
He says he wants to be back here by Xmas.
Well to return to our flight.
We left Chungking
at 9 A.M.
and flew East through beautiful
country very much
like Lake George except the broad Yangtsze is coffee color
rather than blue.
China is much more enjoyable from the air
than from the
surface because
you see only the beautiful
green country and you miss all the squallor, dirt and most
unpleasant of
Someone was asked if he knew
the Chinese National Anthem.
He replied that at no
had he ever heard the National air but that he could smell it
almost anywhere.
Our first landing was at
Wahnsien which is
a quaint city at the upper end of the gorges.
From there we
flew close to the river
through the gorges which rise steep
on either side from 500 to 1500 feet.
There we flew for a
hundred
miles about 30 feet off the water. (It is now Sunday
morning and again I am flying down
the Yangtsze with Shanghai
as our last stop.
We have just left Chekiang where the ship
which we
were supposed to take back to Shanghai yesterday
part to ward or and me den to lamen met us at there
float - the engine is in bad shape and the plane will have to
be loaded on to a river boat and shipped back to Shanghai. The
and mechanic will stay with the ship until it is loaded.
I asked Norris
to buy me some Chekiang china which is quite
famous and I
think very beautiful - it is called "thousand
flowers"
wrote to you about it once before.
The flowers
are all different colors against a blueish gold back ground or
a black back ground.
I ordered the lighter back ground and
will send one of the plates to
you for your approval or
disapproval.
If the latter, I can easily dispose of them in
Shanghai
at more than Norris will pay for them.
thought he
could get a fairly good set of six pieces each
for $60.00 Mex.
or $15.00 our money.
To go on with my story of
the gorges -
we passed
many picturesque
junks with their
delapidated sails,
miscelaneous cargos struggling up stream against
current and white capped
rapids of the muddy snarling Yangtsze.
A rope is attached to
the mast of the junk - a long long bamboo
twisted rope - trackers frequently stark naked strain with all
their
bare feet gripping the tow path worn
smoothe by
generations of their sweating chanting grunting
ancestors who for thousands of years have fought up stream along
same path towing the same
type of cargo in the same kind
of junks.
The latter vary in design so that experienced
observers can tell at a glance where the junk is from.
of them will
travel from Shanghai
to the borders of Tibet.
places along the cliffs the tracker path is hewn out of solid
rock and the trackers,
from six to ten men depending on the
size of the tow,
cling to
the narrow path with rock above their
heads - one shoulder rubbing the cliff and the other above a
yawning
chasm 100 feet above the river where a slip means just

- 3-
one more Chinese ancestor.
"Chilly" comes down lower still
and passes close to a river steam boat which appears to be
standing still but is actually running with every horse in its
horsepower pulling his darndest against the swift current.
Crew
and
passengers wave as we flash by -
just caught a glimpse of
the flag,
a gentle
it was British.
We take the bends of
the river with
banking turn - the air is smoothe - it should be
rough -
both
our two Chinese companions
- a man and his wife are
asleep, apparently old
customers of Chilly's.
Along the
steep
sides
of the
gorges wherever
any
soil
is available
terraced
rice fields get a rest while the farmer coolies watch
us
pass
they never change
expressions
or wave.
Little shrines
are
carved out of the rock at many
places and ocassionally you
see a small
pagoda.
the
Emerging from the
gorges we land at Ichang -
break bulk station and
and lower
out
Yangtsze.
transhipment point between the upper
Ichang is known for canes which are carved
of a tree root.
for
I had radioed
our agent to have
some there
me
to
look at and bought three for $1.00 Mex. each. (We have
just
landed
to deliver and take on mail at Anking - our station
there
is
in
which
raft like pontoon and attached to it is half a junk
is
a waiting room.
We stayed there a few minutes and
then take
off for Nanking.
Anking.
It
We fly
over the ancient city of
is entirely surrounded by a high wall
with a moat.
One gate - is the only entrance on the river side and one on
the land
side.
We have one Chinese passenger
who wakes up only
to get out at each station and take a smoke.
blue
gown and a skull cap like Guido Pantaleoni wears) We
arrived
at Hankow Friday afternoon - it was quite hot 88°
the shade and my winter suit was uncomfortable. Chilly's boy
pressed it for me which at least made it look more presentable.
We had dinner at Chilly's and then went to a movie "Tomorrow
and Tomorrow".
I had seen it before but didn't say so because
they all wanted to go and it was
the only movie in town.
day A.M. we
saw Chilly off for Chungking again and
Satur-
went shopping.
I bought
some "shorts"
with stockings to match - olive drab -
and felt much more comfortable - also felt (but
wasn't) more
conspicuous •
We had lunch at Chilly's place and as it was
raining just sat around
until
the plane, in
which I am now
writing,
came in at 3 o'clock.
Then we went
out to the club
and had
a swim after which we drank tea on the
porch - watched
a cricket game "just Iwancy" and listened to a band, or rather
wi th
"God
amid much bumping of glasses and
toasts - it was
the king's birthday - quite an event it seems among the English
who seem
to control
the Hankow Club as
well
as
every other
club in China except the American and French
Clubs at Shanghai.
The cricket
game was
the first I have ever seen and I found
it much less boring than I expected - probably because one
American was playing and refused to make futile passes at the
ball but instead took a full man-sized baseball
swing
and
knocked the ball out of the lot every time the "bowler" threw
the ball toward his wicket.
After the American had
scored
45 runs the game was stopped for some reason - probably for tea
or perhaps
they despaired of ever getting him out.
However all
the Britishers gave him a great hand and didn't seem to resent

- 4-
his breaking
un-American
up the game.
in
He also was very modest and
the sense of the all too customary swash
buckling braggart type.
As a matter
of fact the Chinese
classify all
white men as "foreigners" and there is a
resultant spirit of comradie which is quite refreshing and
aften you
French
entirely forget whether your companion is English,
or
what have you.
We are now approaching Nanking the present
Capital of China.
Except for the immediate section around
about here and the recognition by foreign governments Nanking
is a Capital
allegiance
in name only.
The far away provinces pledge
the National Government but they pay in practically
no taxes
and
the various generals (or bandits - until they win)
fight it out for control.
They give nothing to,
montre anything to the National easily at Nant ne
guess its about
the same as the U.S. in the
last analysis -
except
the people of China do not have to put up with a Senate
and Congress and you must admit that is one blessing which
far to
goes
make up for many hardships.
Over here a man in public
life can
eat
Swifts bacon without any
danger of impeachment for
favoring
big
Senate
I
business.
When I read of the actions of the U.s.
can
not help but admire the Chinese system.
Here at
least a leader of men must be a real man among his fellows - he
must possess a keen quick mind and a two fisted virility.
Oh
well
anyhow Nanking.
Leaving Nanking we have another passenger
who we learn from the station manager is Mr.
Chen, Police
Commissioner of Hankow, formerly Police Commissioner at Shanghai.
I'm told he lost his job at Shanghai because he caught the
Mayor smuggling opium at which job it seems the Mayor had been
working for several years quite
to the advantage of said Mayor's
bank account.
Mr. Mayor was given someother job and the Police
Commissioner was
told to
be less zealous.
I guess they were
afraid he might get "too high up on the hog" as brother Bill says.
Wel
one - Our finst Chinese passenger just got a
little touch of air sickness.
As Gent Shelton said of
Speed
Elliot - "he is two
shades whiter than a swan".
Must quit now.
We're approaching
Shanghai and
I must pack up and really go back to hard work after
inspection trip.
Lots and lots of love
Bix
Yound six lettres herr
from you and the
guls -
# from you and
the Each from the gives.
